texts.shortText:
Very distinctive colonial species, with clusters of independent upright zooids all joined at the base. The zooids are usually blue but sometimes yellow or colourless and almost completely transparent, such that the organs can be seen within. There is a darker blue band between the two siphons.

Some of the supposed colour variants may in fact represent undescribed species and genetic work would be needed to confirm this.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to probably KwaZulu-Natal ( tropical forms may be genetically distinct species).
Found attached to shallow reefs in areas of rapid water flow. Little else known about biology.

All ascidians are filter feeders, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.

Colonies expand and grow via asexual reproduction (budding of existing zooids), but new ones are established only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop.

The bright blue or yellow zooids are distinctive and unlikely to be confused with any other temperate species. Several other similar transparent blue ascidians occur in more tropical parts of South Africa though.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 246).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Southern Underwater Research Group, Hout Bay (p. 196.)

Kott, P (2005). Pycnoclavella (Tunicata: Ascidiacea) species from the West Indian Ocean. African Zoology, 40(2), 205-212.
